Lesson 1: Finding and Keep High Quality Staff 

Hire

  • Advertise
  • Include a new hire interview statement
  • Offer competitive wages, within your budget
  • Offer benefits
  • Develop partnerships with organizations
  • Look for the right fit

Train

  • Invest in your program with training
  • Conduct initial 60-day, 6 month, and annual check-ins
  • Get feedback

Support

  • Have their back
  • Allow for creativity
  • Show you value and appreciate them

Even if you correctly follow all of these important hiring steps, it can still be challenging to find and keep high quality staff.

According to www.childcare.net, the turnover rate for child care employees is one of the highest of any occupation. Turnover is a challenge across the field. Let’s look at some strategies that you can do throughout the hiring and on-going support phases of working with and retaining staff.

Hire

  • 1. Advertise!

  • Advertise!

    Not only is it additional publicity for your program, but posting your job opening to an online newspaper or Craigslist site can also get your job opening in front of a much wider employee market! Local colleges and community colleges are also another source to consider for job postings.

  • 2. Include a New Hire Interview Statement.

  • Include a New Hire Interview Statement.

    Not only will this provide you with a written sample from the applicant, it will also help you see what their values and beliefs are relating to children, working with families, and working with others. While answers could be made up that sound good, take some time to ask applicants for more information when you interview them. Be sure if you use this form that you use it with every applicant for the position you’re interviewing for. Otherwise, an applicant could claim that they were discriminated against during the hiring process.

  • 3. Offer competitive wages, within your budget.

  • Offer competitive wages, within your budget.

    Be sure you keep your budget updated so you know how much you’re able to offer staff. Do your homework to learn what a local competitive wage is and be sure that you set your child care rates high enough to cover program costs, including offering a competitive wage.

  • 4. Offer benefits.

  • Offer benefits.

    While not every program will be able to offer full benefits such as medical or dental insurance, you can offer other benefit options to staff such as Paid Time Off, holiday, or vacation pay. Knowing what you can offer means knowing what your budget can support, so, be sure that you keep your budget updated! Develop partnerships with organizations. Look outside your program and with local businesses. Some local businesses offer discounts to teachers! Take advantage of this and see if they will extend these discounts to your staff. It never hurts to ask, and you’ll never know until you ask!

  • 5. Look for the right fit.

  • Look for the right fit.

    Taking your time to find candidates with the right job fit and organizational fit may take longer during the hiring process, but it will reduce turnover and save you time in the long-run.

Train

  • 1. Invest in your program with training.

  • Invest in your program with training.

    The ability of any organization to accomplish its goals depends on a skilled and capable workforce! Quality doesn’t just happen, it’s always the result of intentional effort, which includes training efforts! Be sure you encourage and provide training opportunities both within and outside of your program. If you’re on a tight budget, you can still offer excellent professional development! Lead a book study with your staff, or, for FCC providers, read a book yourself! Some excellent ones for staff discussion include: Einstein Never Used Flashcards and Mind in the Making (both available on Amazon). NAEYC also offers a wide range of resources and suggested books that would also be good resources.

  • 2. Conduct initial, 60-day, 6 months, and Annual Check-ins with all staff.

  • Conduct initial, 60-day, 6 months, and Annual Check-ins with all staff.

    Staff development is an on-going process. After a well-designed on-boarding (training) process, be sure you are checking in to see how things are going, offering a refresher if needed, and helping staff to develop new skills or take on new responsibilities as they are ready for them.

  • 3. Get feedback.

  • Get feedback.

    Leaders (that’s you!) who want to keep their fingers on the “pulse” of their programs regularly check in with staff and parents alike. Weekly conversations with staff around the following questions can help you stay connected, help staff feel supported, and help keep your program growing!

    Questions to ask the staff:
    • How was your week?
    • What are some successes you’ve had this week?
    • Are there any problems you’re having that I can help you with?
    • Do you have any concerns about the overall operation of the program or any suggestions for improving? Versions of these can also be asked to parents in the program!
